did.abstract: Collection contain images related to two photography projects by Sarah Hoskins. The Homeplace series contains 250 11x14 inch silver gelatin prints documenting Hoskins' visits and relationships with rural African American communities in Kentucky, originally established by freedmen in the 19th century. Her photographs include community events and activities such as hog butchering, church services, family reunions, and gatherings of charity groups. The Rosenwald Schools series contains approximately 300 color digital images of schools for African Americans built during the first half of the 20th century through the Rosenwald foundation, as well as some portraits of former students in Kentucky, North Carolina and Alabama. The series also includes images of a Rosenwald foundation-funded apartment building in Chicago, Illinois. Acquired by the Archive of Documentary Arts.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection contain images related to two photography projects by Sarah Hoskins: The Rosenwald Schools and The Homeplace.

The Homeplace series contains 250 11x14 inch silver gelatin black-and-white prints documenting Hoskins' visits and relationships with rural African American communities in Kentucky, originally established by freedmen in the 19th century. Her photographs include community events and activities such as hog butchering, church services, family reunions, and gatherings of charity groups.

The Rosenwald Schools series contains approximately 300 color digital images of schools for African Americans built during the first half of the 20th century through the Rosenwald foundation, as well as portraits of some former students in Kentucky, North Carolina and Alabama. The series also includes images of a Rosenwald foundation-funded apartment building in Chicago, Illinois.
Acquired by the Archive of Documentary Arts.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Sarah Hoskins is a Midwest-based documentary photographer; currently her time is split between Chicago and Lexington.

physdesc.physfacet: (250) 11x14" Silver Gelatin Prints in 5 flat boxes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Homeplace documents the traditions and daily lives of African American communities in Kentucky's Inner Bluegrass region that were originally founded by freed slaves following the Civil War. As Hoskins states:

"Today many of the residents are descendants of the freed men and women who founded these hamlets. In some cases as many as six generations of a family have lived in succession on a "homeplace" in these communities. Some of these hamlets are prospering while the exisitence of others is tenuous."

The Homeplace documents events such as hog butchering; harvesting and drying tobacco; worship services at community churches; service group meetings, such as the Union Benevolent Society Lodge; creekside baptisms; and family reunions, meals, and gatherings. Each print has been assigned an RL ID and includes Hoskins' original title and caption.

scopecontent.p: The barn where the hog killing is to take place. Empty tub and table. "There has to be frost on the ground." Ernest Talbert tells me in order to kill hogs. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.p: The barn before the hog killing begins. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.p: Leroy Talbert has just fired the shot, Gary Talbert on left, Rodney on right. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The hog had been shot, but had not died yet. Leroy was tring to quicken the process using a knife. RJ Hayes and Regind Happy hold the hog back as Rodney Talbert leans in. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Leroy, Gary, and Rodney Talbert push the hog down in the scalding tub of Lye. I met Leroy and most of the others for the first time that night. Leroy glared at me and said, "we're here to work." He is my dear, dear friend now. We laugh as it could have gone the other way had I fallen from the slick table I was standing on. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: L-R Gary, Leroy Talbert, Amos Coma, RJ Hayes, and Regind Happy. The smell, the steam, and the heaviness in the air were so thick you could cut them with a knife. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.p: The hog has now been scalded in the hot tub of lye. This makes it easier to scrape the bristles off the hog. L-R Rodney Talbert, Amos Coma, RJ Hayes, Leroy Talbert. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: RJ Hayes scraping off the bristles. Regind Happy next to him on right. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Regind Happy and Gary Talbert have made a slit in the back of the legs near the tendon, which is how they will hang the hog. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Regind Happy putting in spool to hang hog. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: RJ Hayes watches as Amos Coma takes the spool to lift the hog with Regind Happy helping him. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Derek Talbert hoses the hog. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Derek Talbert sharpening knife. The group of men killed and cleaned 13 hogs in 3 hours. The men did this after they all had worked other jobs all day. New Zion, KY.

did.unittitle: Uncle Joe and Hogs from the Night Before.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Uncle Joe bringing the hogs down to be butchered from the barn next door. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The next morning it was the older men who came to do the butchering. I asked Uncle Ernest (back then I called him Mr. Talbert) why that was. "The younger ones don't have the interest to learn." L-R Eddie Moore, Fredrick Clay, Joe Mason and Ernest Talbert. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: L-R Joe Mason and Fredrick Clay sharpening knives. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Johnny and Winston Figgs hanging out in what I called "The Club" behind Ernest Talbert's house. It is where they would meet, hang out, butcher the hogs, and maybe drink a bit. I asked Uncle Ernest once how many women had been in there and he said≈Æ"well maybe Sarah Relford and you." I was honored. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Uncle Joe stirring cracklins. It took me a long time to learn Uncle Joe's last name. When I asked those who knew him really well they didn't know his last name either. Everyone just knew him as Uncle Joe. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Johnny Figgs fries himself up some dinner in "the club." New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Queenie belonged to Uncle Ernest. He was the lead man and in charge of the hog killing and the butchering. It was his garage and his mother's barn where this was all done. Anyone who knew Ernest knew of his hams. He was famous for them. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gene Brown waiting for the rest of crew to plant. One thing about everyone in all of these communites is they always make sure to hire someone who needs work. Everyone always makes sure that everyone is taken care of. Willa Lane, KY.

scopecontent.p: Winston Figgs in his barn tossing tobacco. He had told me the day before at church that he would be stripping tobacco in the barn the next day. I had been all over the barn, but never knew this room was there. In fact, I couldn't even find it until I heard Al Green coming from the portable radio. New Zion, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Doug loading up Winston Figgs' truck to bring tobacco to the last live auction. Again, Winston Figgs helping someone who maybe needed help or work. What I know and knew of Doug was that he was a bit slow, his parents had died, and everybody kind of just made sure he was OK. Outside of Maddoxtown, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Winston Figgs sits in the office as they tell him they can't find his paperwork. As Duke has requested, I am trying to keep these captions short. This is a story I will write. All I can say is after the treatment of him this day I can't imagine back in the day. Lexington, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Keene, Kentucky. The road hasn't changed much but the barns signs often do. Keene, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is on Overbrook Farm, where Tom (Preston) Embry now lives. He is well into his 80s and always worked with the horses. I met him years ago. He is Clara Jackson's nephew and from the hamlets. He and his wife needed someplace to live and they let him live back here. There is always a spring house, deep in history and in this land. Overbrook Farm, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These dogs were behind Bunny Beatty's house in Fort Spring. I believe the dogs were rasied and sold by his grandson. The dogs, like Bunny, are long gone. I believe it was that grandson who built a pretty new house up the lane. Fort Spring, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is Macey Simpson's home in Pricetown. She invited us to her Labor Day party. She told the story of how they buried her old house. She now lives in a new trailer. Pricetown, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is the old Hall church and outhouses. The church now empty. Hall was the hamlet right across the way from Camp Nelson. Hall, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cooley Clay in paddock at Keeneland. Cooley knows EVERYONE! His brother Buck worked there as well. Buck played for the Kansas City Monarchs. Keeneland Racetrack, Lexington, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joe Edwards working in the winner's circle at Keeneland. He is one of the Jimtown Male Chorus members. Keeneland Racetrack, Lexington, KY.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ernest Talbert was≈Æno words. He was my buddy. As I look at the captions so far and dates, I realize how much I stepped away from this work. Not much from 2008 as he died in Oct. 2007 and I struggeld as I missed him so. Here he is in the grandstand looking like he owned it. He worked in the paddock before he got sick then they moved him up here. Keeneland Racetrack, Lexington, KY.

One of the all-time special moments. New Zion, KY.

did.physdesc: Consists of 303 computer files, approximately 10.3 gigabytes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rosenwald Schools series contains 303 electronic records documenting school buildings built by the Rosenwald Foundation. As Hoskins writes: "In my work each photo project leads to another. The Rosenwalds school is no different. It stems from The Homeplace project. Finding a Rosenwald school is like finding buried treasure. The problem in photographing comes in a number of ways. The first is I am often trespassing and second I am often there at a time of day when the light is not the best." Electronic records are chiefly digital images with a few text documents describing the locations Hoskins visited. The photographs document the schoolhouse buildings themselves exteriors and interiors, as well as nearby structures and occasionally local residents.

accessrestrict.head: Access restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room. To request access, please contact Research Services before coming to use these records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document the Rosenwald school building in Boydtown, Kentucky. Hoskins writes: "It wasn't until 2013 that I photographed this school. I had been in the church behind it back in 2006 and some other times as well. The church had been closed prior to 2006 and the congregation merged with New Zion which is how I learned about through Rev. Lyle Morton who used to pastor at both. It now stands empty waiting to decide what will happen to it. The school has been a home for a number of years. I spoke with the owner who said she moved out there because it was so quite but is now concerned as the subdivisions in Georgetown are getting closer and closer."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document the Rosenwald school building in Cadentown, Kentucky. Hoskins writes: "I have been to this school numerous times over the past 14 years. The first visit was back in the fall of 2001. I remember as it was my first trip after 9/11 in October. The school was empty and in disrepair. The Cadentown Baptist Church which was in front to the school had been sold and had been made into a private residence. Back on that first visit on a early Sunday morning I knocked on the door. There was no answer, I ignored the No Trespassing signs and went around to the back and photographed the school (though I did not know anything about Rosenwald Schools at the time). I also photographed the outhouse but was most intrigued by the cemetery as it was in a strange state. There were red flags posted next to the grave stones and it just felt odd. It wasn't until the next spring that I learned of all the controversy. Apparently the people who bought the church and made it a home did not welcome people visiting the old cemetery and there was talk of moving it. The owners had put a fence up towards the front of their home which is where the signs were the no trespassing signs were posted. I heard stories that it turned pretty nasty. My friend Jonetta Young and her mother Helen who lived down the road in Cadentown fought for a long time to save the school and cemetery as well as halt a new white church that was being built. The white church was across the street from their home and the school. The building of the new church caused flooding to theirs and neighboring homes. Also the white church was tearing up old grave sites. Jonetta hired a "cadaver dog" and the story made the Herald Leader,( the Lexington paper.) I know that I have images of old grave stones that were moved. Kind of like the movie Poltergeist. The new white church eventually went up. The graves paved over for a parking lot. Jonetta moved away with her mother Helen who I heard got Alzheimer's and passed away. She was a lovely woman whose Birthday was close to mine. We always sent Birthday cards and it was Jonetta and Helen Young who introduced me to the Howard sisters. Helen Young had been a student at the Cadentown school, her teacher had been Lena Mae Howard. It was Jonetta and Helen Young who I followed out to meet and photograph the Howard sisters in Uttingertown over 10 years ago. I also photographed Helen Young in front of the school for American Legacy magazine back in 2003. I heard stories that Jonetta had been threatened by people and I believe that to be true as she worked so hard and was such an advocate to save the school and Cadentown. I heard from her once by email out of the blue thanking me for my work I had been doing. I wrote her back thrilled to hear from her but never heard back again. I think it is a tribute to her that the school survived, but I feel so bad that somehow she got lost along the way."

scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document Rice Chapel which stands next to the site of the Dry Ridge Rosenwald school building. Both buildings had been moved to a park in Crittenden. Hoskins writes: "The school was burned, arson was the cause in 2012. The Ku Klux Klan had spray-painted a racial epitaph on the school prior to it being burned."

When he first told me about Sadieville the Baptist church was still going and he and the chorus had gone there to sing. He thought I might be interested in the church and school."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document the Cecil JR Brown Rosenwald school building in Montgomery County, Alabama. Hoskins writes: "I heard about this school on the way home from vacation. I feel it is one of the most beautiful schools. The door was open and so I went in. My husband and daughter standing outside and watching, as again there was No Trespassing signs posted. I came outside to find them talking with a white woman who said she and her fox hunting group owned the property, which I learned later was not the case. I found some information on the school and it listed the family who actually did own the school and property and whose relatives had attended the school. I sent the owners some photos and we have stayed in touch. I came home one day to find a box of pecans sent to me as a thank you for the photos. The pecans came from a tree on the property where the school stands."

scopecontent.p: The image in this subseries documents the Rosenwald school building in Maddoxtown, Kentucky. At the time this image was taken, the building was used as a home. Hoskins writes: "I know both students and teachers who went and taught here and confrimed that this was the school it has been a home for a very long time."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document the Mayo Rosenwald school in Mercer County, Kentucky. Hoskins writes: "The images in color here where not from my first visit to this community. I originally went there with my friend MaryAnn Meaux. She had told me about her uncle who was the last African American in the hamlet and that he was having an auction of all of his things and invited me to come and photograph. He was going to be moving into town or a nursing home. I do not remember which but I do remember the rain. It was pouring for most of the day. I also remember I saw him in his truck watching the auction and crying. There are photos of all of this from The Homeplace project. That is how I learned about this school. The school as not far from where the auction was. Like many it was next to a church. This church is loosing its members at a rapid pace as the elders are passing away. As for now on my last trip both school and church are standing in good shape."

scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document the Park Ridge Rosenwald school building in Gallatin County, Kentucky. Hoskins writes: "I learned about this school from Moe Ware. I met him at Maddoxtown Baptist Church photographing The Homeplace project. He had grown up in this community and took me to photograph the school. At one time it was a pretty thriving black hamlet but like several communities all that is left is the church and if lucky the school as is the case here."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document three school buildings in Garrard County, Kentucky: Scott's Fork, Garrard County, and Flatwoods. The Scott Forks school is a Rosenwald building. The Garrard County building may be. The Flatwoods building is probably not a Rosenwald. As Hoskins writes: "I was heading to Flatwoods, Kentucky as Rev. Travis and his wife Billie from Maddoxtown, KY said that he had been to preach down there and mentioned I should head over there as there was a small school behind the church. I hadn't remembered the name Flatwoods at first but once there I realized I had been there once before. Charles Hunt who was related to Georgia Blair from Sugarhill had told me that it was an old hamlet. The photos are included here from Flatwoods though I do not think it is a Rosenwald school at this point. However the other school just titled Garrard County looks very possible. The structure looks right and you can see where the windows were changed. Still need to research more. Then there is the Scott Forks School! First I could not believe the location I had never been or photographed a Rosenwald so tucked in and low. Down, down in a long valley at the base near pretty much near nothing. It seemed so out of place as did I getting there. Maybe it was the fact that it was further south then I had been since the car accident maybe the fact that the roads leading to it were insane. Maybe it was meeting a huge pickup coming out of the mud on a road on a blind curve that was barely a lane next to a creek. I visualized the dully truck the rebel flag waving running me off and into the creek. A lone cow in the middle of the road around a bend. You get the idea. Then as the road ends and T's. There it sits. I don't know that I have ever been as stunned to see a Rosenwald school, still there, still standing in a valley so low I didn't know that we would get out of there alive. Not to mention the Pit Bull and the gun shots from the inside of the school, but what a reward finding it. I have also included some of the roads leading to the school. How can you not include a lane called Sad Lane."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document the Jouett's Creek Rosenwald school in Hootentown, Kentucky. Hoskins writes: "When I first went to Hootentown back in 2003 to try and locate this black hamlet I learned about the church and school. My friend Betty Smithers from the hamlet of Jonestown was with me. We saw the sign marked Hootentown Lane, but the turn and lane where so tight and straight up we had to turn around and come back at it. We then realized it was too steep to come in that way and had to turn around again. Finally we headed up and in. There was a split as you drove up the lane and we took the one to the right. It dead ended at the top of the hill. Two large big burly white men, an older woman and a middle age woman and two kids were there. We were pretty much stuck as the road ended into their trailer. Betty rolls down the window and says," We're here looking for the black hamlets. " I figured this was it , the guns were being loaded. Then the middle aged woman named Cheryl Bryant says, "well honey I am the blackest thing out here come on out." She said we were lucky we didn't take the other lane or he would have started shooting. She showed us how to locate old grave stones by looking for honey suckle plants. We found some from the old hamlet and then she told us about the church down below. " I sometimes go sit behind my trailer on the side of the hill and listen to them singing on Sunday." She pointed the way and told us how to go out and quickly turn left. That is how I first came to this school. We had completely missed the lane to the church. We found our way into the lane and over the single lane bridge that led to the church. I held my breath as we crossed over it hoping we would make it to the other side. I felt sure I felt it sway. We pulled into and onto the gravel and there was a car parked. It was a Saturday. I walked up and could hear a vacuum cleaner running and knocked. That was how I met Bobby Hart. He showed us in and around and when I asked about the small building behind the church he said, "It was an old school, someone from Sears built it." I have spoken with the Rosenwald Foundation and they feel it is the Jouett's Creek school. The photos match up, it had been listed in the wrong location. As of 2012 there is a sign that says Jouett's Creek Lane up the road, which helps confirm it is correct. I am sure this is right.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document the Nicholasville Colored School (also known as Rosenwald Dunbar High) in Nicholasville, Kentucky. Hoskins writes: This is now an apartment building with at least 9 different apartments. You can see on some of the detail shots how the facade has changed and windows have been bricked over. Tribly and Charles Railey were both students at the Rosenwald School,l they have lived here all their lives. Tribly used to live across the street but her memory is slipping so she now lives with her brother Charles. About five or six years before these images were made my friend Don Moore brought me out here to show me the school. His wife Gladys Moore had gone to the Cadentown Rosenwald school and he knew I would be interested.I mention all of this because when Don and I were out taking pictures back around 2005 Charles opened his door to see what I was doing but when I asked could I take his picture he said no and went back inside. His house is two away from the school. Fast forward to 20012 my daughter Emma and I are out front taking pictures of the school and Charles opened up the door and beginning waving at me say, "I remember you, you were here before taking pictures before." and waves me right on in his house. It was a happy surprise, I kind of wonder if he was worried about us as much of the neighborhood had fallen on a bit of hard times and there were some guys across the street who were a bit intimidating not to mention more than a bit drunk. For whatever reason it was a welcome surprise to be welcomed into their home. They talked and shared stories of the school and offered us candy. We were able to leave them with a bunch of Butterscotch brownies that Emma had made. Good people a good visit."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document school buildings in Warsaw and Eminence, Kentucky. Of Warsaw, Hoskins writes: "We had driven into Warsaw as Pastor Travis was from the area and we were exploring. I happen to see an African American man and got out of the car and asked him if her knew of any old black schools. He told me how to get to the Warsaw school which was where he went. He gave me directions which led me to this school.Itl is not listed in any records I have found but I am sure it is correct because of how it looks." Of Eminence, she writes: "Emma and I drove down a dead end road and saw this older African American lady and her son on their front porch. Over the years I have learned if you can find someone of a certain age who is black they will know about the schools. That is why I asked them. She said there was an old black school and offered to show us. They got off their front porch and into a car and said to follow them which we did. It wasn't far but is was passed a closed and posted no trespassing sign and dilapidated building. Then through an opening of some trees. It was by no means a road. I began to wonder what we were doing. We got out and there didn't seem to be anyone home. We were greeted by many No Trespassing Signs and dog warnings. I took a quick photo. The mother and son were very kind and they told us we should really be careful and not so trusting of people. Which was funny as it was crazy where we had just followed them to. They worried about us and asked if we wanted them to take us back to the highway. We thanked them and headed on our way. Pretty sure this is a school and it was indeed an adventure. It is hard to tell by this photo but there was one in Eminence, Kentucky Henry County which is where this was and it is listed on this street. However you won't know it was a street anymore because it is actually behind the street and through the trees."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Not sure.Was brought here by an older lady who went here. She said it was a Rosenwald. Hard to tell if it was one but there was one in Eminence, Kentucky Henry County which is where this was.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document former students of the Zion Hill Rosenwald school. Hoksins writes: "I have included images here of some former Rosenwald students from Zion Hill. We got everyone together for a group photo for a piece I was doing for Preservation magazine in front to the historic marker that references the Rosenwald school that used to be there. It ended up being a truly special day as some of the students hadn't seen each other in years. Zion Hill has worked extremely hard to have their community recognized. It is also one of the communities I have been photographing for years for The Homeplace project."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document the Rosenwald school building in Browntown (now Scott's Hill), North Carolina. Hoskins writes: "This school was pretty easy to find sitting next to the side of a busy road. One of those roads that is leading you into 'vacationland' as I sometimes call it. My family vacations have a tendency to end on a quest for Rosenwald schools. I kind of smile as I write this thinking of all the over-priced nick nacks inside and wondering if they knew the value of the beautiful sign on the front of their building. I asked the building and they said it had been a school once but needless to say their interest in the building didn't seem too deep and I didn't feel like I should press it. It was a good thing we found this one as the next attempt ended up with a 150 mile side trip to a vacant lot."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The images in this subseries document the Rosenwald school builidng In Wise, North Carolina. Hoskins writes: "There are several reasons I am convinced this is a Rosenwald school. The first and what might seem the strangest is the comment I received as I stepped out of my car with my camera in hand. There was a large white man standing with a chain saw who looked more than a bit intimidating. I asked if it was OK to take a photo of the building. "Yes, it is an old white school. " I think it was the fact that he made such a point to say it was white school that really led me to believe it was a Rosenwald school for black children. We wandered around and he came over and told us (my daughter and I) that he owned the school and allowed us inside to make photos. There were signs saying Ruritan Club which I had never heard of at the time,however I have seen them more frequently now in the south. The wood and windows looked right for a Rosenwald as did the cloak room. Over the years that is one thing that many of the elders who went to the schools is the cloak rooms. This one had one as well and truly matched up."

scopecontent.p: One of things that those who went to Rosenwald schools always mentioned was a cloak room. Which leads me to believe even more that this was and is a Rosenwald school.
